body: By default ZAP does not scan URL path elements. Try enabling that https://www.zaproxy.org/docs/desktop/ui/dialogs/options/ascaninput/#url-path and let us know if ZAP now detects these issues.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19234081/79114521-12229e80-7db6-11ea-97ae-8d6d4e3b5251.png)
I have URL path enabled from here as demonstrated in the screenshot.

From the screenshot that I pasted in the issue description, I think I have successfully enabled zap to scan url path elements because it is attacking using the url path params as well

I take it that ZAP did not detect the SQLi issue then?
Can you describe how your application behaves when you submit specific SQLi payloads?
Its one thing to manually detect a specific vulnerability in a specific application manually, its very different to then program that into rules which apply to any application.
It seems it's being used the wrong encoding in the variant.

rename.from: ZAP cannot detect SQL injections from route param
rename.to: ZAP cannot detect SQL injections through path parameters

body:
@psiinon here is my full code, just a simple flask app without doing anything special
```
from flask import Flask
import psycopg2

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/api/user/<name>')
def main(name):
    try:
        conn = psycopg2.connect(
            database = "penTest",
            user = "postgres", 
            password = "postgres",
            host = "localhost",
            port = "5432")
        with conn.cursor() as cursor:
            cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE name = '%s' " % name)
            result = cursor.fetchall()
        conn.commit()
        conn.close()
        if result:
            return f"{result}"
        else:
            return "no data"
    except Exception as e:
        return f"{e}"
```

> It seems it's being used the wrong encoding in the variant.

Do you recall what made you think the encoding was wrong?

I just did a quick test and amongst other things got a scan request like `http://demo.testfire.net/images%27+AND+%271%27%3D%271%27+--+/header_pic.jpg ` which seems correct to me. The issue might be that like the command injection rule the SQLi rule(s) seem to send the original value concatenated with the payload. To accomplish what's mentioned above (`http://127.0.0.1/api/user/' or '1'='1'--`) it would seem we'd need something like `http://demo.testfire.net/%27+AND+%271%27%3D%271%27+--+/header_pic.jpg` .

Or am I missing something else?

Not only recall but still have the branch with changes for this issueâ€¦ the en/decoder used is not correct for the path component (e.g. spaces should not be encoded as `+` but `%20`).

You can tweak the example above to see that, without requiring a DB:
```Python
from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/api/user/<name>')
def main(name):
    return f"{name}"
```

If you access `http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/user/+or` it will output `+or` not ` or`, so what the scan rule is actually injecting in the query is `'+or+'1'='1'--` not `' or '1'='1'--`.
Ok, should I bother looking into it further or do you have something to PR?
Need to check the changes, I'll let you know shortly.

rename.from: ZAP cannot detect SQL injections through path parameters
rename.to: Path input vector not properly encoding values

body: I can open a pull request, have more changes than needed to address this issue so will remove them.

issue.title: Correct encoding/decoding in URL path variant

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Do not rely on `URLEncoder` to encode the path segments as that's not
the correct encoder for the URL path.
Handle and decode the path segments separately to preserve the encoded
values on each segment.
Keep the segments extracted when parsing the URL path to avoid doing it
each time a parameter is set.
Remove commented code.

Fix #5935.
